quote: Etana...
I know you're back there...   don't make me come after you.
Give me that...
You don't need this.
Yes... I... do...
Commander Riker to the   Enterprise. I've got a problem   down here on Risa!
Give it to me.
Go get it.
I can't believe you did that.
Believe it.
What's this?
It's a game. Everyone here's   playing it.
Do I keep my eyes open, or   closed?
Open.
What am I seeing?
The playing field.
Now what?
See the disc and the cone?
Yeah...
Concentrate... Make the disc go   into the cone...
How do I do this?
Relax... just let go. You'll do   it.
Got it.
What was that?
Your reward. For clearing the   first level.
How far does this game go?
As far as you can take it. You   want to try for level two?
Captain's log, stardate 45208.2.   Commander Riker has rejoined the   Enterprise from Risa. And we are   on our way to an uncharted area   called the Phoenix Cluster.
We are all anticipating this   historic first look at the   region.
Things are getting busy around   here. Five more science teams   just beamed in from the Zhukov.   Quarters are filling up fast.
And on top of everything, there's   been a change. We now have only   two weeks to complete the   exploration.
Two weeks... that's not enough   time to explore a region that   size. I thought we had five   weeks.
Starfleet has added a diplomatic   mission to Oceanus Four.
Will, I'm leaving it up to you to   make sure all science departments   have an equal chance to complete   their research.
It'll be quite a juggling act.
A bit of good news, as well.   We're to rendezvous with a   shuttlecraft carrying Wesley   Crusher. He's on vacation from   the Academy.
Wesley... good. We'll need an   extra hand around here.
Geordi... how are you coming with   the survey preparations?
I'm up to my neck in observation   schedules right now.
Our biggest hurdle is sensor   availability.
Especially since two new   exobiologists and three stellar   cartographers joined us from the   Zhukov.
Fifteen science teams, only two   weeks, and one long-range array   don't make a great combination.
What about the lateral sensors?
They're booked solid for   planetary observation.
And the gamma ray scanner?
We're reprogramming it now...       Lefler... will you join us,   please?
You know Robin Lefler.
Of course.
Her performance around here has   been sensational. I've decided   to make her a mission specialist.
Congratulations.
Thank you, sir.
Okay, specialist -- what's our   sensor status?
We're increasing the available   bandwidth... so more science   teams can use the sensors at   once. We figured out a way to do   it by multiplexing the array.
Will it be ready by the time we   arrive?
Yessir. You can count on it.
Keep it up, Lefler.
Geordi... I brought something   back from Risa. You've got to   try it.
I'd love to. But I'm running a   full sensor recalibration in ten   minutes. Can it wait?
Sure. I'll catch up with you   later.
Chocolate ice cream. Chocolate   fudge. Chocolate chips. You're   not depressed, are you?
I'm fine, Commander.
Did you want to be alone with   that?
No. You can join us.
I don't like fudge.
Really. I never met a chocolate   I didn't like.
Doesn't it taste good?
Of course it does. But it's not   just a matter of taste. It's the   whole experience.
First you spoon the fudge from   around the rim... leaving only   ice cream in the middle...       Then gently spoon the ice cream   around the sides, like you're   sculpting it...
Relish every bite. Make every   one an event. And on the last   bite, close your eyes...
I never knew it was a ritual.
Chocolate is a serious thing.
You know... I brought something   back from Risa. It's better than   chocolate.
Oh... what is it?
Just a game.
Chief O'Brien!
Welcome back, Wesley.
Congratulations on little Molly.
Thanks. Wait till you see her --   she's the spitting image of her   dad.
So... where is everyone? Is my   mom around?
The senior staff is holding a   meeting. You're supposed to go   to your mother's quarters.
Oh. Well, do you think it'd be   alright if I stopped by... just   to say hi?
I'll check.       Chief O'Brien to bridge.
Bridge here.
Wesley Crusher has arrived and   wants to know if he can stop by   the observation lounge...       To say "hi".
That is acceptable.
Thanks.
Welcome home.
Thanks, Mom.
Wesley...
Captain...
Quomodo tua Latinitas est?
Praestat quam prius. (It's   better than before.)
Oppido bonum.  Your   Latin has improved.
You're looking very handsome.
You do that cadet uniform   justice, Wesley.
Bet you drive the girls wild.
Tarvokian pound cake. I made it   myself.
Thanks, Worf.
Wesley -- was our attempt to make   you uncomfortable effective?
You bet it was. For a second   there, I thought I was on the   wrong ship.
And you found the deception   pleasurable?
Well... yeah. It's fun to be   surprised.
Are you here to work or play,   Mister Crusher?
Sir?

I know you're on vacation.   You'll probably want to sleep   late, and go to the holodeck.   But if you'd like to help out, we   could use an extra hand in   preparing for the Phoenix Cluster   survey.
That'd be great, sir.
After you're settled, come down   to engineering. We'll get you   started.
Aye sir.
What kind of game?
Come by my quarters, and I'll   show it to you...
Have you found the Academy   challenging, Wesley?
After the Enterprise, I thought   it would be a breeze... but   there's a lot more to learn   besides starship operations.       How was your first year?
Although I did extremely well   scholastically, my lack of Human   understanding often created   social obstacles.
Like what?
I particularly recall a   phenomenon called practical   jokes, several of which I fell   victim to.
Tell me about it. My first week   there, a guy named Adam Martoni   reprogrammed the sonic shower to   cover me with mud. It took me a   while, but I got him back pretty   good...
I also found social gatherings   difficult. There was one event,   an Academy tradition, something   called the Sadie Hawkins Dance.
Yeah... they still hold it every   year.
It was a notably awkward   experience.
Don't worry, Data... I can't   dance either.
Really? Your mother is quite an   expert. She recently taught me.
Yeah, I know. "The Dancing   Doctor." She tried to teach me.   I just don't seem to have the   knack.

I would be happy to give you   lessons while you are here on   vacation. I have created a   comprehensive seventeen part   course with some interesting   holographic dancing partners.   Several members of the crew have   become quite proficient...
I'll let you know, Data.
I'll try modifying the planetary   scanners.
Just make sure we keep enough   data lines open for stellar   physics.
No problem. I'll compress the   signal flow...
(to himself, re:     console)   Now why won't these register... ?
You might try calibrating them   manually.
Excuse me?
The detectors. They tend to get   temperamental. Try calibrating   them by hand.
Are you kidding? It's gotta be   done by the computer.
No, it doesn't. Here...
This subroutine will let you do   it from the panel...
Law Seventeen -- When all else   fails, do it yourself.
It's working...
Thanks.
Sure.
I'm Wesley, by the way... Wesley   Crusher.
I know. Just came back from the   Academy.
That's right.
Robin Lefler.
Hi.
Hi.
Your neutrinos are drifting.
What? Oh!
A conflict has started between   the planetary evolution team and   the stellar physicists. Both   wish to use the thermal imaging   array first.
Well... tell them to flip a coin.   They've got to cooperate on this   mission, or we'll never get it   done.
A coin. Very good. I will   replicate one immediately.
Crusher to Data.
Go ahead, Doctor.
Do you have a minute to join me   in sickbay?
Yes, Doctor. I am on my way.
You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Yes, Data. I need your help with   something.
I'm running a new experiment on   bioactive silicon. Would you   reprogram the tricorder to these   specifications?
Certainly.
Sorry to bother you with this,   but I need it done quickly.
It does not bother me. In fact,   I am happy to --
Computer -- secure sickbay.
All entries to sickbay are   secured.
Let's see... I had Novakovich for   anthropology... and Horne for   creative writing...
Walter Horne... is he still   teaching?
And you'll be happy to know, I   took your advice. The first week   I was there, I went to meet   Boothby.
Is he still tending the   grounds... or has age finally   caught up with him?
Not that I can tell. He took me   on a grand tour... showed me   every single blade of grass,   practically.
I got the very same tour...
Sir... what do the initials S-P   stand for?
Boothby said he once found you   carving those initials into his   prized elm tree.
Oh... just an old acquaintance.
Wesley. If you meet someone   whose initials you might want to   carve into the elm tree, try not   to let it interfere with your   studies.       I failed organic chemistry   because of S-P.
Crusher to Captain Picard.
Go ahead, Doctor.
I need you in sickbay   immediately.
On my way.
He came in to complain about a   servo malfunction. My scans were   coming out negative. And then he   just... collapsed.
What have you found?
His biosystems and positronic   functions seem to check out. And   his power cells are active...
From what I can tell, his higher   functions are intact. But the   signals aren't getting from his   brain to the rest of his body.   It's like he's in a coma.
Data performs self-diagnostic   routines on a regular basis. We   should take a look at his logs --   they might tell us something.
I recommend searching his   quarters, as well. You never   know what might turn up.
Agreed. Continue your analysis.   Keep me informed.
Standard security sweep shows   nothing out of the ordinary.
Personal logs, diagnostics, duty   logs... they all look normal. No   evidence of anything leading to   Data's shutdown.
Maybe we should ask his cat.
I'd better get back to sickbay.   See if there's any change in his   condition...
Doctor Crusher's got a handle on   it, Geordi. You'd be the first   person she'd call...
I guess so...
Looks to me like you need a   break... unwind a little.
Maybe you're right.
I know just the thing.       Why don't you meet me in Ten   Forward? I've got something I   want you to try.
Conduits twelve and twenty-two   are still down for testing.
We can re-route through junction   fourteen B...
You have a funny way of looking   at conduit configuration. But it   works.
Law Thirty-Six -- You gotta go   with what works.
What are these laws you keep   talking about?
My own personal laws. When I   learn something essential, I make   up a law about it. That way, I   never forget.
How many laws do you have?
One hundred and two... so far.
Looks like the starboard array   needs another subprocessor.
Don't worry, it'll be on-line in   a few minutes. I'm way ahead of   you.
They said you were good.
Why do I get the feeling you   already know me?
I have a couple of friends at the   Academy. Your name's come up a   few times.
That was some prank you pulled on   Adam Martoni in the physics lab.   I just want to know how you got   the antimatter regulator to spray   chili sauce.
Uh... there's another side to   that story...
And is it true about your   birthmark?
This isn't fair. I know nothing   about you.
Law Forty-six -- Life isn't   always...
... isn't always fair. I know   that law.
I've gotta go work on the sensor   relays. But later, I want a   chance to even the score.       Ten Forward, nineteen hundred   hours. Will you join me for   coffee?
No.       But I'll join you for dinner.

Captain's log, supplemental. We   have arrived at the Phoenix   Cluster, but it will take us   several hours to determine the   best possible location from which   to conduct our survey. In the   meantime, Commander Data's   condition remains unchanged, with   no further indication as to the   cause of his breakdown.
Mom?
Wesley...
What are you doing?
I'm embarrassed to say this was   meant for you. But it's so much   fun, I couldn't resist.
What is it?
A game. Will Riker brought it   back from Risa.
Everybody's playing it. Would   you like to try?
Maybe later.       Any word on Data?
Geordi's still working on him.   He's going to be fine.
Maybe I should give Geordi a   hand...
No, Wes. This is your vacation.   You're doing more than enough   already.
I guess you're right.
Are you in a hurry?
Well, actually... I'm running   behind schedule for a dinner   date.
Really. With who?
Robin Lefler -- from engineering.
Why don't you invite her over?   We can all play the game   together. I'll replicate a   couple more.
Mom...
Sorry. I just want to spend some   time together while you're here.
We'll spend lots of time   together. I promise.
Okay.       Come on, just one game. Try it   on for size...
I need to change now.
Have a good time.
Thanks.
When your parents are the only   exobiologists in the sector, you   do a lot of travelling around.   Base to base to base...       After a while, I felt like a   piece of luggage.
I spent most of my time around   technical gear. My very first   friend was a tricorder.
Really? Mine was a warp coil.
My parents weren't around much.   Even when I needed them... their   work always came first. That's   how I learned my first law. Law   One -- The only person you can   rely on is yourself.
Sounds lonely.
And now you're here.
Now I'm here.
I'm glad.
You wouldn't believe what's   happening in engineering.   Commander La Forge and the   others... they're crazy about   this new game.
Game?
Some Risian gadget. A little   thing that fits over your ear.
Have you played it?
Not yet.
My mom has one. She was trying   to get me to play it.
It's everywhere.
See what I mean?
It's strange, don't you think?   Everybody playing it all the   time...
It's a fad. This week it's   popular, next week we won't even   know it existed.
I wonder how it works?
Why don't you try it and find   out?
I'd want to know more about it   first.       We could hook it up to a   computer. The medical programs   can simulate human brain   responses...
The game uses a visual   interface... we could connect it   through an optical sensor...
Okay... I've loaded the   neurological behavior program.
This sensor pad should allow the   computer to process whatever   information the game throws at   it.
Let's see what happens...
It's activating the reticular   formation...
Heavy synaptic activity... all   over the place...
I wonder what happens after   prolonged exposure...
Speed up the processor and we'll   find out.
The effects are centered in the   frontal lobe.
Computer, enhance frontal lobe --   full spectrum.
It's stimulating the septal   area...
... The pleasure center of the   brain. Whatever this game does,   it must feel pretty good.
No wonder it's popular.
Wait a second... look at this.   Serotonin levels are way off.   Let's do a neurochemical   analysis...
I'm seeing widespread bonding to   neuroreceptors...
Correct me if I'm wrong, but this   looks like a psychotropic   reaction.
Are you saying you think the   game's addictive?
What's going on in the prefrontal   cortex?
Doesn't that area control higher   reasoning?
Yeah... it sure does.
I'd better talk to the captain.
Come.
Sorry to bother you, Captain.
No bother at all, Wesley,   please...
How are the survey preparations   coming along?
Fine, sir... but that's not why   I'm here.
Oh... why then?
There's a game going around...   something Commander Riker brought   back from Risa. A little device   that hooks around the ear...
Yes, I've seen it.
I did some preliminary tests on   the game. What I found leads me   to believe it may have harmful   side effects. Specifically sir --   I think it's psychotropically   addictive.
Addictive... What have you   discovered?
The game initiates a serotonin   cascade in the frontal lobe of   the brain. Now I know that's   nothing conclusive... but it   could be the reason people are so   attracted to it.
And at the same time, it seems to   be stimulating the brain's   reasoning center... I don't know   what that's all about...
We'll start an investigation   immediately. Thank you, Mister   Crusher.
And Wesley...
Good to have you back.
Thank you, sir.
Have you tried this?
I've tried it, thanks. It's   great.
Robin...
Sorry.
Where have you been? Everyone's   been after me to play.
Me too. I was stopped twice in   the corridor.
I spoke with Captain Picard.   He's going to look into it.
I hope he makes a shipwide   announcement or something...       This is starting to give me the   creeps.
Did you forget your games?
We left them in our quarters.
Well then... you can use mine.
No thanks...
She said no thanks.
There's something else bothering   me about all this -- if the game   is addictive... there's only one   person on the ship we can be sure   wouldn't be affected by it...
Data.
Right. And he just happened to   get injured at the same time this   game was brought on board.
I think we should take a look at   him.
The nurse is still playing the   game.
I don't know what to make of   this. There's brain activity...   all his systems seem to be   working.
How can that be? He's   unconscious.
There might be a signal breach   somewhere... between his brain   and his body. Let's map his   nervous system... see if we can   isolate a weak link...
Still nothing...       Here.
The signal stops here. Below his   cognitive processor.       There's some kind of damage...   almost undetectable...       Turn on the viewer.
Wesley, look.
It looks like some of his   positronic links have been   severed.
The cuts are very precise... see   how clean the edges are?       Computer, increase magnification,   factor four.
Only two people on board know   enough about Data to have done   something like this. Commander   La Forge... and my mother.
Why would one of them do this to   him?
Maybe there's more going on here   than we thought. Someone could   be trying to use the game -- for   some purpose other than   pleasure...
If that's the case... Data would   have been a threat to that   plan... but with him out of the   way, everybody else could become   addicted.
And everybody has. Except us.
We've reached the designated   coordinates, Captain. There is   a ship bearing three-two-seven   mark one-five-two on an intercept   course.
Advise them of our status, Mister   Worf.
Go replicate what you need. See   that the devices are properly   distributed.
(continuing; an     afterthought)   And don't forget Mister Crusher.
Wesley?
Wesley?
In here, Mom.
It worked.
Better keep the mock-ups with us.       We can't trust anyone now. Not   even the captain.
I'm supposed to be on duty in   engineering. I've gotta get back   before Commander La Forge   suspects something.
When you get there, start   accessing the codes for the   security tracking system.   There's something I want to   try...
Wesley. Don't forget Law Ninety-One...
Always watch your back.
You too.
The vessel is approaching,   Captain.
All senior officers report to the   bridge.       On screen.
Report.
The Enterprise has been secured.   We await your further   instructions.
The expansion will proceed as   follows...       Commander Riker.
Pilot a shuttlecraft to these   coordinates...
You will rendezvous with the   Starship Endeavor. Resume   distribution of the device aboard   that vessel.
Commander La Forge and Counselor   Troi... take a shuttle to   Starbase Sixty-seven. Distribute   the device to all starships   currently docked there.
We also have an opportunity to   introduce the game to Starfleet   Academy.
Excellent. See to it.       The Ktarians commend your   efforts, Picard. When the   expansion is complete... you and   your crew will be rewarded.
Deck thirty-six.
I think we're gonna be okay.   I've just got one more thing to   do...
Help me compile the forcefield   overrides...
What are you doing?
I created a site to site   transporter program. If things   get difficult, this'll keep us   one step ahead...       Did you get a chance to access   the security tracking codes?
Robin... ?
It's your turn, Wesley. Play the   game.
Computer -- activate security   containment field on deck thirty-six,   section fifty-two!
Computer -- transport program   Crusher One!
Riker to bridge. We've lost   Crusher. It looks like he rigged   a site to site transport.
Security alert, condition three.   Computer, shut down all   transporter systems and shuttle   bays.       Mister La Forge?
I can't track him, sir. He's   done something to the internal   security sensors. I'll try   bypassing his subcommands. Hold   on...
I'm picking up a piece of his   trail, sir -- sensors show power   activation in transporter room   three. That would put him   somewhere on deck six.
Seal off deck six. Activate   security fields on section twenty-   three through twenty-nine.
Aye sir.
We've got him, Captain -- section   twenty-five. It looks like he's   trying to break through the   forcefield with a phaser.
Security to deck six, section   twenty-five.
Where the hell is he?
I am attempting to isolate him   with thermal sensors...
Narrow the scan field. Go deck   by deck if you have to...
Unfortunately, he knows our   procedures... he will avoid   corridors and public areas...
I am reading an unidentified heat   source on deck seven, section   twenty-three...       There...
You gave us quite a chase, Mister   Crusher.
Doctor Crusher...
Hold him steady.
It's okay, Wesley. It doesn't   hurt. You'll like it. I promise   you...
No...
His eyes.
No...
That's it, Wesley... just let   yourself go...
Computer, resume normal   illumination.
Mister Worf, you will find a   small alien ship off the   starboard bow. Secure it with a   tractor beam and raise our   shields.
Engaging tractor beam.
Are you all right, Captain?
I think so...
Captain, we are being hailed by   the alien vessel.
On screen.
Picard, explain yourself.
The explanation is simple -- your   attempt to capture this ship has   failed.
Release us immediately. Or we   will open fire.
Tactical analysis, Mister Worf?
Their weapons capability is   substantially inferior to ours.   They are not a threat.
Get her off the screen.
I can't believe what we were   about to do...
Data... we deactivated you...
I managed to reconnect his   positronic matrix.

Wesley's subsequent diversions   gave me adequate time to modify   the palm beacon...       The optical burst patterns we   programmed were successful in   counteracting the addictive   effects of the game.
And the rest of the crew?
We have programmed the main   computer to transmit the same   optical pulse to all display   screens, work stations and   terminals throughout the ship.
That'll reach almost everyone.   Send out medical teams to treat   the rest.
Aye sir.
We'll take the alien vessel to   the nearest Federation starbase.   Ensign, lay in a course.

Captain's log, stardate 45212.1.   We have delivered the Ktarian   vessel to Starbase Eighty-two.   We are now on a course to   rendezvous with the Starship   Merrimack, which will take Wesley   Crusher back to the Academy now   that his vacation is over...
I never saw you wear these.   Afraid someone might see your   birthmark?
Who started that birthmark rumor,   anyway?
Wish you didn't have to go.
Me too.
You'll write, won't you?
Somebody's got to kill those   rumors you keep hearing about me.
Mister Crusher, we've   rendezvoused with the Merrimack.
Please report to transporter room   two.
On my way, sir.
I'd better go.
Here...
A gift. So you'll remember.
Robin's Laws. All one hundred   and two of them.
Law number one hundred and   three...
Yes?
A couple of light years can't   keep good friends apart.
